title: 108_s2981
content: The Act titled "Conventional Arms Threat Reduction Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It includes findings and the sense of Congress. The global proliferation of MANPADS, small arms, light weapons, and tactical missile systems poses a direct threat to US national security. Their use by terrorists hampers peace efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan, while the spread of missile systems threatens international peace and security. The proliferation of tactical missile systems poses a threat to international peace and security. The Government Accountability Office estimates there are 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS worldwide, with many countries no longer needing such weapons for their security. The Government Accountability Office estimates 500,000 to 750,000 MANPADS worldwide. Many countries have these weapons but lack the means to eliminate or secure them. There is no US program to address conventional arms threat reduction and tactical missile elimination in other countries. The United States lacks a program to address conventional arms threat reduction and tactical missile elimination in other countries. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund for this purpose since 2002. The Department of State has not used the Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund for any activity to eliminate tactical missile systems since 2002. Congress believes the US should assist countries in securing, removing, or eliminating proliferation threats like MANPADS and small arms linked to terrorism networks. The United States should provide assistance to countries in securing, removing, or eliminating stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. There should be a consistent emphasis on combating the proliferation of these weapons within the broader nonproliferation strategy. The United States aims to assist other countries in safeguarding or eliminating stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat through a global program. The Secretary of State is authorized to implement a global program to secure, remove, or eliminate stocks of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems that pose a proliferation threat. This program may include activities such as humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms and light weapons, and securing or eliminating tactical missile systems and MANPADS. The program authorized under subsection (a) may include activities such as humanitarian demining, destruction of small arms and light weapons, securing or eliminating tactical missile systems and MANPADS, and cooperative programs with international organizations. Programs authorized under subsection (a) include assisting countries in safe handling, storage, and elimination of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems through cooperative programs with international organizations. Funds can be utilized for these purposes. The curr_chunk focuses on the management and utilization of funds for the elimination or safeguarding of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems. It also mentions actions to ensure equipment and funds are used effectively in securing these weapons. The curr_chunk emphasizes the management and security of MANPADS, conventional weapons, and tactical missile systems funded by the United States. It includes actions to ensure equipment and funds are used appropriately for securing these weapons and preventing proliferation threats. The Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction is established within the Department of State to formulate policy and administer programs for reducing conventional arms threats. Additionally, a report on conventional arms threat reduction is required to be submitted. The Secretary of State must submit a report on conventional arms threat reduction to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The report will detail prior Department of State efforts, progress in establishing the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, and country-specific descriptions. The report to congressional committees will include descriptions of prior Department of State efforts, progress in establishing the Office of Conventional Arms Threat Reduction, and country-specific implementation of a global strategy for eliminating or safeguarding conventional weapons. The report to congressional committees will include an evaluation of the integration of activities under this Act and other US Government programs to ensure consistency with US policy and goals in countries receiving assistance. The report required under this Act will evaluate the integration of activities to ensure consistency with US policy and goals in countries receiving assistance. It will also describe US programs related to the elimination of tactical missile systems in unclassified form, with a possible classified annex. SEC. 7. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 authorized for the President in fiscal year 2005 under this Act, with a limitation of $10,000,000 until the Secretary of State submits the required report. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. "Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund" is defined as a fund established under a specific section. "Small arms and light weapons" include various types of firearms. The Nonproliferation and Disarmament Fund, established under section 504 of the FREEDOM Support Act, defines "small arms and light weapons" as various types of firearms. The curr_chunk describes various types of weapons including machine guns, grenade launchers, antiaircraft guns, antitank guns, missiles, rockets, mortars, ammunition, explosives, hand grenades, landmines, and more.
